item.title: Study Links Polluted Air in China to 1.6 Million Deaths a Year
item.description: A research group’s findings may complicate the Chinese government’s efforts to clean up the capital city of Beijing ahead of the 2022 Winter Games
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: A woman and child waiting on a roadside this month for a highway from Beijing to Hebei Province to reopen. It was shut because of low visibility on a day of heavy smog.

item.title: Message Believed to Be From Qaeda Leader Pledges Support for Taliban
item.description: The voice of Ayman al-Zawahri, who has not had any confirmed audio or video communications since September, was identified in a message acknowledging the Taliban’s new leader.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape
item.description: Claiming the Quran’s support, the Islamic State codifies sex slavery in conquered regions of Iraq and Syria and uses the practice as a recruiting tool.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Letter From Europe: British Media Takes On Calais Migrant Crisis in ‘Silly Season’
item.description: In the summer, when most officials are on vacation, Britain’s newspapers are full of overheated “controversies." The migrant crisis has been a great boon.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on the French side of the Channel Tunnel last month.

item.title: U.N. Faces Scrutiny Over Unpaid Intern Who Slept in a Tent in Geneva
item.description: The intern who said he could not afford housing in Geneva has called on unpaid interns around the world to unite, and the world body to live up to its own ideals.
item.category: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Venezuela Releases Two Prominent Government Critics From Prison
item.description: The releases of Raúl Baduel and Daniel Ceballos come as the government works to weaken opposition ahead of legislative elections set for December.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: The former mayor of San Cristóbal, Daniel Ceballos, center, looked out from his Caracas apartment with his family on Wednesday. Mr. Ceballos, who had been held on charges related to widespread antigovernment protests last year, was released to house arrest.

item.title: Shinzo Abe’s Bid to Redefine Japan and Its Military Has Echoes of Family History
item.description: Mr. Abe, who wants the military to take on limited combat roles, sees himself in the mold of his grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, a premier who helped redefine cooperation with America after the war.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: President Obama with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan in April. Questions have been raised about how far Japan should go in rebuilding its military power and whether it should broaden the reach of its security partnership with the United States.

item.title: Europe Gives Google More Time to Respond to Antitrust Charges
item.description: The move comes just days before an Aug. 17 deadline that Europe’s competition authorities had set for Google to respond to the accusations.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and CONOR DOUGHERTY

item.title: Turkish Coalition Talks End Fruitlessly, Making New Elections Likely
item.description: The failure of Turkey’s two largest political parties to form a coalition after June elections sets the stage for a new vote and threatens further instability.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Mustafa Aktas/Prime Minister's Press Office, via Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, right, and Turkey's main opposition leader, Kemal Kilicdaroglu, left, met Thursday in Ankara.

item.title: Sweden Drops Some Sex Cases Against Assange
item.description: Swedish prosecutors on Thursday dropped cases of lesser sexual misconduct against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange but said they still want to question him on accusations of rape made after his visit to Stockholm five years ago.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Julian Assange is at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London.

item.title: Berlin Journal: In a Maligned German Arts Quarter, Much Is Riding on a New Museum
item.description: The Kulturforum has long foiled urban planners and frustrated Berliners, but many hope that will change when a new home for modern art is built there.
item.dc:creator: JESSE COBURN
item.media:credit: Djamila Grossman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Philharmonie, home to Berlin's philharmonic orchestra, behind an empty lot where a new museum of modern art will be built. The Kulturforum, Berlin's arts district, is also home to two libraries and a number of other museums.

item.title: Prominent Rights Defenders Convicted in Azerbaijan
item.description: A court in Azerbaijan on Thursday convicted a prominent rights defender and her husband on fraud charges, which international rights groups have denounced as a sham.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Greek Island of Kos, Overwhelmed With Migrants, Tries to Move Them Along
item.description: As the government tried to speed up the evacuation of Syrians and other migrants from the island of Kos, some migrants said they had been locked in a stadium.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.media:description: Migrant women carrying children comforted one another on the Greek island of Kos after crossing part of the Aegean Sea from Turkey.

item.title: China Seeks to Calm Markets as It Devalues Currency for 3rd Consecutive Day
item.description: The renminbi’s official rate against the dollar has fallen 4.4 percent over the last three days, but officials in Beijing said it was not in free fall.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: Studying stock charts on Thursday at a brokerage firm in Shanghai. After two days of declines, the Shanghai composite index rose 1.8 percent on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Woman Dies After Stabbing Near Uniqlo in Beijing
item.description: The police said they had arrested the assailant, whom they identified as a 25-year-old man with the surname Gao from the city of Tonghua in Jilin Province.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW and MIA LI

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Brazil’s Vigilante Lynchings
item.description: In cities, some Brazilians resort to mob violence against criminal suspects, blaming weak policing and courts.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA BARBARA

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Plight of Refugees, the Shame of the World
item.description: Children are resilient when given a chance. It’s a shame how few are.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ZEYNEP TUFEKCI

item.title: Violent Backlash Against Migrants in Germany as Asylum-Seekers Pour In
item.description: In the first half of this year alone, as more than 179,000 people applied for asylum, Germany’s Interior Ministry recorded 202 attacks on housing for them.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Truck Bomb Kills About 60 at Market in Baghdad Neighborhood of Sadr City
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the blast in the Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City, which came just after dawn as shoppers were stocking up for the weekend.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: The aftermath of a truck bomb at the Jameela market in the Sadr City neighborhood of Baghdad on Thursday.

item.title: Hong Kong Convicts 2 in 2014 Cleaver Attack on Journalist
item.description: Kevin Lau Chun-to sustained severe cuts in the attack, which heightened concerns about threats to press freedom in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
